Cu-Co nanoparticles supported on nitrogen-doped carbon: An efficient catalyst for hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural into 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan Wenguang Zhao Investigation Methodology Data curation Writing – original draft a Xiaoting Zhu Investigation Methodology Formal analysis a Zhijuan Zeng Validation a Jing Lei Formal analysis b Zexing Huang Visualization a Qiong Xu Resources Writing – review & editing a Xianxiang Liu Conceptualization Project administration Funding acquisition Supervision a ⁎ Yongjun Yang Resources Funding acquisition b a National & Local Joint Engineering Laboratory for New Petro-chemical Materials and Fine Utilization of Resources, Key Laboratory of the Assembly and Application of Organic Functional Molecules of Hunan Province, Hunan Normal University, Changsha 410081, China National & Local Joint Engineering Laboratory for New Petro-chemical Materials and Fine Utilization of Resources Key Laboratory of the Assembly and Application of Organic Functional Molecules of Hunan Province Hunan Normal University Changsha 410081 China aNational & Local Joint Engineering Laboratory for New Petro-chemical Materials and Fine Utilization of Resources, Key Laboratory of the Assembly and Application of Organic Functional Molecules of Hunan Province, Hunan Normal University, Changsha 410081, China b Chenzhou Gao Xin Material Co., Ltd., Chenzhou 423000, China Chenzhou Gao Xin Material Co., Ltd. Chenzhou 423000 China bChenzhou Gao Xin Material Co., Ltd., Chenzhou 423000, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Production of the 2,5-Bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF) has important scientific value and strategic significance for the development of new biodegradable polyester materials. Herein, Cu-Co/NC composites containing bimetallic nanoparticles in nitrogen-doped carbon were produced by the calcination of zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs). They featured a cubic Cu-Co core and a porous structure derived from the ZIFs. The surface morphology, surface area, and composition of the catalysts were analyzed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscope (TEM), thermogravimetric (TG) analysis, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray diffraction (XRD), CO2-temperature program desorption (CO2-TPD), and N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms. A conversion of 93.7% of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) with a BHMF selectivity of 92.4% was achieved using the Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 catalyst at a relatively low reaction temperature and H2 pressure. This outstanding catalytic performance was ascribed to the high dispersion of Co nanoparticles in the NC framework, forming Co-Nx species. We found that the synergistic catalysis of Cu-Co sites due to electron transfer contributed to the increase in the BHMF selectivity during HMF hydrogenation. The intensity of the XRD peaks corresponding to metallic Co decreased as the calcination temperature increases, which results in agglomeration of Co nanoparticles (NPs), and reduces the catalytic activity in HMF hydrogenation. Additionally, the conversion of HMF during hydrogenation remained stable after using Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 for ten cycles. Graphical abstract Cu-Co nanoparticles supported on nitrogen-doped carbon exhibited superior catalytic performance in the selective hydrogenation of HMF into BHMF. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biomass 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural 2,5-Bis(hydroxymethyl)furan Copper-cobalt bimetallic catalyst Nitrogen-doped carbon 1 Introduction With the increasing demand for energy and the concurrent increase in environmental pollution, the development of new sustainable resources and green chemical processes has been the focus of scientific research for a few decades. Biomass resources have long been considered as a promising alternative to fossil fuels because they offer many superior advantages, such as a low cost, abundance, and diversity, as well as the possibility of being regenerated by photosynthesis. Therefore, biomass is the most suitable and inexhaustible raw material for the sustainable production of fine chemicals and biofuels, justifying the rapid development of research on its catalytic conversion [1]. Synthesized by the dehydration of biomass-derived carbohydrates such as glucose or fructose, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) is considered as one of the most important compounds during biorefining because of its multifunctional structure, which contains hydroxyl and aldehyde groups and a furan ring [2,3]. The hydrogenation of HMF can be carried out to synthesize many high-value compounds, such as 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF), 5-methylfurfuryl alcohol (MFA), 5-methylfurfural (5-MF), 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF), and 2,5-dimethyltetrahydrofuran (DMTHF). Among them, BHMF is highly attractive because of its unique symmetrical diol structure and a broad range of applications in the production of polymers [4–7], crown ethers, pharmaceuticals [8], resins [9], plasticizers [10] and artificial fibers [11,12]. Consequently, it has received increasing attention from scientists. To date, many researchers have developed a variety of metal catalysts using Pd [13], Au [14], Ru [15], Pt [16], Zr [17], Ni [18,19], Co [20,21] and Cu [22,23] for the hydrogenation of HMF into BHMF. Mishra et al. achieved a 98.5% yield of BHMF using a Ru/MnCo2O4 catalyst at 100 °C and 8.2 MPa H2 for 4 h [15]. Chen and coworkers designed Pt nanoparticles (NPs) encapsulated into zeolite Y that exhibited approximately 100% catalytic selectivity to BHMF at 80 °C and 2.0 MPa H2. This high selectivity was ascribed to the zeolite Y constraining the adsorption geometry of the reactant HMF on the encapsulated Pt surface, increasing the activation energy between the aldehyde and hydroxyl groups [16]. However, the industrial applications of precious metal catalysts are restricted by their high cost and loss by leaching. Sarkar et al. reported a BHMF selectivity of 98.0% and HMF conversion of 100% using a Cu@C-POP-B catalyst at 150 °C and 2.0 MPa H2. The presence of Cu vacancies on the CuO surface stabilized the transition state and decreased the hydrogenation barriers, resulting in an enhanced catalytic activity of the Cu@C-POP-B catalyst [22]. Furthermore, Zhang et al. developed Ni/HC catalysts that can efficiently catalyze the hydrogenation of HMF at 160 °C and 1.5 MPa H2, resulting in a 5-HMF conversion of 94.0% and BHMF selectivity of 93.6% [18]. Although a high BHMF selectivity was obtained in the abovementioned studies, high reaction temperatures or high H2 pressures were used in these systems. Thus, the selective hydrogenation of HMF under mild conditions remains a challenge. Metal organic frameworks (MOFs), often referred to as porous coordination polymers, have received immense attention for diverse catalytic applications owing to their distinct geometric structures, large internal surface areas, and high densities of uniform and tunable active sites that can promote a high catalytic activity [24,25]. Previous studies demonstrated that the use of MOF supporting materials led to excellent results in the hydrogenation of HMF [26]; however, their industrial applications are limited to their shortcomings, which include the leaching of active metals, instability at high temperatures, and aggregation of NPs [27,28]. Consequently, MOF-derived porous carbon materials are preferred by researchers because their highly ordered structure helps the atomic dispersion of metal species and prevents aggregation during carbonization [29]. For example, Sarkar et al. synthesised CuPd bimetallic nanoparticles embedded in carbon matrix (CuPd@C) by simple pyrolysis of Pd impregnated Cu-based MOFs. It found that the entrapped bimetallic nanoparticles with carbon shells in Cu-Pd@C-B catalyst protect the active catalytic site from migration, aggregation, and leaching during hydrogenolysis reaction and improve the stability of the catalyst [30]. Recently, nitrogen-doped carbon-supported metal catalysts have received considerable attention because nitrogen doping significantly affects the physicochemical properties of carbon, such as the coordination between nitrogen and carbon atoms, resulting in enhanced electron transfer ability and the stabilization of metal NPs [31]. Therefore, metal NPs supported on nitrogen-doped carbon materials exhibit excellent catalytic properties. Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) are a subclass of MOFs with a zeolite-like topology. ZIF-9, a particular ZIF, consists of tetrahedrally coordinated metal ions (Co cations) linked with imidazolate moieties (benzimidazole ligand). Owing to the uniform pore structure and abundant incorporated N species, ZIF materials are a promising template for the preparation of nitrogen-doped carbon catalysts [32]. In this work, we prepared bimetallic NPs in a nitrogen-doped carbon catalyst for the selective hydrogenation of HMF into BHMF. Specifically, a series of Co and Cu NPs on nitrogen-doped carbon were prepared by the calcination of Cu-Co-ZIF-9, composed of an organic ligand (benzimidazole) complexing with metal ions. During carbonization, the structures of the original Cu-Co-ZIF-9 were preserved, and metallic Co and Cu NPs were generated in situ on the nitrogen-doped carbon matrix to form Cu-Co/NC with tunable Cu content. The resultant Cu-Co/NC exhibited outstanding catalytic activity and stability for the hydrogenation of HMF to BHMF under mild reaction conditions. Furthermore, the calcination temperature, content of doped copper, and reaction conditions (such as temperature, time, catalyst, and H2 pressure) were investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate, cupric nitrate trihydrate, sodium formate, tetrahydrofuran (THF), N,N-dimethylformamide, and octane were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., and were all of analytical grade. Benzimidazole (99.9%) was purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. HMF (98.0%) was purchased from Shanghai D&B Biological Science and Technology Co., Ltd. BHMF (98.0%), MFA (95.0%), and 5-MF (98.0%) were purchased from Shanghai Bidepharm Technology Co., Ltd. All chemicals were used without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts 2.2.1 Synthesis of CuxCo1-ZIF-9 CuxCo1-ZIF-9 was prepared by solvothermal crystallization using benzimidazole as the organic ligand. Following a general procedure, 1.009 g of sodium formate and 0.995 g of benzimidazole were dissolved in 25 g of N,N-dimethylformamide. After stirring for 30 min, an appropriate amount of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate and cupric nitrate trihydrate were added dropwise into the mixture under stirring. After stirring for an additional 30 min, the mixture was transferred to an autoclave, sealed, and crystallized at 160 °C for 36 h without stirring. A purple precipitate was observed after the reaction. The product was collected by filtration and washed thoroughly with ultrapure water and ethanol. Finally, the product was dried at 60 °C for 12 h in a vacuum oven. The synthesized catalyst precursor was denoted as CuxCo1-ZIF-9, and the mole ratio of Cu:Co was x:1 ( Scheme 1 ). 2.2.2 Synthesis of CuxCo1/N-C-T First, an appropriate amount of CuxCo1-ZIF-9 was placed in a combustion boat and calcined in a 10% H2/Ar atmosphere at a specific temperature (400, 450, 500, 550, or 600 °C) for 4 h at a heating rate of 5 °C/min. Subsequently, the furnace was cooled to room temperature in a hydrogen atmosphere, and the catalyst, a magnetic black powder, was collected. The prepared catalysts were designated as CuxCo1/NC-T (T = 400, 450, 500, 550, and 600), where T represents the calcination temperature. 2.3 Characterization Thermogravimetric and derivative thermogravimetric (TG-DTG) experiments were performed in a N2 atmosphere using a Netzsch Model STA 409 PC instrument. The surface morphology of the catalysts was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) using a Zeiss Supra 55 instrument and an X-ray energy spectrometer (Zeiss SmartEDX).The crystal structures of the catalysts were obtained by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using an Ultima-IV X-ray powder diffractometer (Rigaku Corp.) with Cu Kα radiation, (λ = 1.5418 Å) operated at 40 kV and 20 mA. The surface area, pore volume, and pore size of the catalysts were determined by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms measured at −196 °C using a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 sorption analyzer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) profiles were collected on a K-Alpha+ (Thermo Fisher Scientific, US) apparatus using monochromatic Al Kα (1486.6 eV) radiation as the radiation source. The morphologies of the samples were investigated by using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) with FEI Tecnai G2 F20. The ability of CO2 adsorption for the catalyst was measured by CO2-temperature program desorption (CO2-TPD) experiment. Prior to adsorption of CO2, the sample (100 mg) was pretreated at 300 °C for 1 h and cool 50 °C in flowing He. At this temperature, sufficient 10% CO2/He (30 mL/min) was injected at least 1 h until adsorption saturation, followed by purging with He (30 mL/min) for about 1 h. The temperature was then raised from 100 to 550 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min to desorb CO2. The desorbed CO2 was detected by on-line gas chromatography with a TCD detector. 2.4 Catalytic testing Typically, a suitable amount of substrate, catalyst, internal standard, and solvent were loaded into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel high-pressure reactor. The reactor was sealed, purged with H2, and charged to the desired pressure, after which it was placed in a furnace at a specified temperature. Upon completion of the reaction, the reactor was immediately cooled with ice water to room temperature. The catalysts were separated by applying a magnetic field. The reactor containing the separated catalysts was purged with H2 and refilled with fresh substrate solution for subsequent catalytic cycles. Subsequently, a filter membrane was used to ensure that the liquid products were free of solid particles. Gas chromatography (GC) was performed using a Nexis GC-2030 instrument (Shimadzu Corp.) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a capillary column (SH-Rtx-1701 30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm). The products and reactants were further identified by gas chromatography–mass spectroscopy (GC–MS, Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010), and the retention times were compared with those of the pure chemicals. All compounds were quantified based on the internal standard method using octane as the internal standard. The HMF conversion and BHMF selectivity and yield were defined as follows: HMF conversion ( % ) = 1 − Mole of HMF Initial mole of HMF × 100 % BHMF selectivity ( % ) = Mole of BHMF Initial mole of HMF − mole of HMF × 100 BHMF yield ( % ) = Mole of BHMF Initial mole of HMF × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts The surface morphology and crystallinity of the Cu0.04Co1-ZIF-9 precursor and Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 were characterized by SEM. As shown in Fig. 1 (a) and (b), the Cu0.04Co1-ZIF-9 precursor exhibits a rhombic dodecahedron shape, which is similar to the structure of ZIF-9 reported in the literature [33], and has an average particle size of 150∼250 nm. However, unlike the smooth surface of the Cu0.04Co1-ZIF-9 precursor, a relatively rough surface is observed in Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 (Fig. 1(c) and (d)). After calcination at 450 °C, the particle size of Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 was smaller than that of the Cu0.04Co1-ZIF-9 precursor, approximately 50–100 nm, and there was a tendency to shift to a spherical shape. Elemental mapping and EDS profiles were used to investigate the distribution of elements in the sample. Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 contains higher concentrations of Co and C compared to N and Cu (Fig. 1(e)), and all elements are evenly distributed on the sample without partial agglomeration (Fig. 1 (f-1–5)). TG analysis of the Cu0.04Co1-ZIF-9 precursor and Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 catalyst was performed in a nitrogen atmosphere, and the results are shown in Fig. 2 . For the Cu0.04Co1-ZIF-9 precursor curve, the weight decreases at different rates as the temperature increases. The weight loss below 180 °C was due to the removal of surface water molecules and crystalline water. A steep curve from 450 to 550 °C is observed, and the weight loss at this stage is rapid, which can be ascribed to the decomposition of Cu0.04Co1-ZIF-9, accompanied by the formation of nitrogen-doped carbon materials. The curve of the Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 catalyst also exhibits a slight weight loss in the range of 450–550 °C, which can be attributed to the decomposition of the residual ZIF structure. The surface composition and chemical states of the elements in Co/NC-450 and Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 were characterized by XPS. All the measurements were calibrated by the C 1 s binding energy at 284.8 eV. The survey spectrum of Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 (Fig. S1) confirmed the existence of Cu, Co, O, N, and C, which further indicated that the Cu NPs were successfully doped into Cu0.04Co1/NC-450. Fig. 3 shows the high-resolution XPS profiles of the Co 2p, Cu 2p, Cu LM2 and N 1 s states of the relevant samples. In the Co 2p XPS profile of the Co/NC-450 catalyst (Fig. 3(a)), the peaks at 777.9 eV and 794.0 eV correspond to metallic Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, respectively. The two peaks at 780.6 eV and 796.6 eV with strong satellite peaks are ascribed to the binding energies of the Co-Ox species. In addition, the peaks at 781.6 eV and 797.3 eV indicate the existence of Co-Nx species [34]. Co-Nx species usually appear in frameworks of nitrogen-doped carbon materials with embedded Co species, where N atoms are bonded to Co atoms. It is noteworthy that compared with the Co/NC-450 samples, the binding energies of the species in the Co 2p XPS profile of the Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 samples were reduced by 1.1 eV. This phenomenon reveals that there may be an electron interaction between Co and Cu, with electrons being transferred from Cu to Co. In Fig. 3(b), we can see that the peaks at binding energies of 933.8 eV and 953.7 eV with strong satellite peaks are ascribed to Cu2+ 2p3/2 and Cu2+ 2p1/2, respectively, indicating the presence of Cu2+ of Cu/NC-450 catalyst. Interestingly, the binding energies of the Cu2+ species of the Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 catalyst are 934.3 eV and 954.6 eV, respectively, which are 0.8 eV higher compared to the Cu/NC-450 catalyst. The result further demonstrates the possible electronic interaction between Co and Cu. In addition, the two peaks located at 932.2 eV and 952.4 eV correspond to metallic Cu0 species or Cu+ species [35]. In order to further distinguish between Cu and Cu+ species, the Auger spectra of Cu were measured, as shown in Fig. 5(c). The Cu LM2 peak with a kinetic energy of 919.2 eV was assigned to Cu0 of Cu0.04Co1/NC-450, which demonstrated the existence of Cu0 species rather than Cu+ species [36,37]. The peaks located at 917.2 eV and 917.3 eV were all assigned to the Cu2+. The N 1 s XPS profile (Fig. 3(d)) suggests that Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 has a nitrogen-doped carbon structure due to the presence of pyridinic-N (397.4 eV), pyrrolic-N (399.7 eV), and graphitic-N (402.1 eV) [38]. Furthermore, the peaks at 398.3 eV and 405.9 eV are assigned to M-Nx (M = Co, Cu) and oxide-N, respectively. Additionally, the O 1 s spectrum can be further fitted into three peaks with binding energies of 529.2 eV, 530.8 eV, and 532.0 eV (Fig. S2), corresponding to M-O (M = Co, Cu), CO, and physically and chemically adsorbed water on the surface of the catalyst [39,40]. The porosity of the catalysts was determined by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, and the specific surface area (SBET), pore volume (Vp), and pore size (dp) of the catalysts are listed in Table 1 . The specific surface areas of the Co-ZIF-9, Co/NC-450, Cu0.04Co1-ZIF-9, and Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 samples were calculated using the Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) method. Interestingly, a comparison between the specific surface area of the Co/NC-450 catalyst (24.83 m2/g) and the Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 catalyst (70.17 m2/g) indicates that doping with Cu atoms resulted in a significant increase in the specific surface area of the catalyst. In addition, compared with the specific surface area (26.29 m2/g), pore volume (0.029 cm3/g), and pore size (9.0 nm) of Cu0.04Co1-ZIF-9, those of Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 increased (70.17 m2/g, 0.113 cm3/g, and 18.0 nm, respectively). These results indicate that the structure of Cu0.04Co1-ZIF-9 changed during calcination and then formed a porous nitrogen-doped carbon material that retained its basic skeleton, which is consistent with the SEM results (Fig. 1). The XRD measurements of the Co-ZIF-9, Co/NC-400, Co/NC-450, Co/NC-500, and Co/NC-600 catalysts are presented to describe the crystal structure in Fig. 4 (a). The XRD patterns of Co/NC-450 show peaks at 44.22°, 51.52°, and 75.85°, which correspond to the (111), (200), and (220) crystalline planes of metallic face-centered cubic Co (PDF#15–0806), respectively. It is worth noting that the same peaks are observed, with lower intensity, in Co/NC-500. Moreover, the peaks at 44.22°, 51.52°, and 75.85° are completely undetectable in the Co/NC-600 catalyst. These results illustrate that the Co2+ that exists in Co-ZIF-9 always forms Co metal NPs during carbonization, and the intensity of the diffraction peaks decreases with increasing calcination temperature. This suggests that the metallic Co gradually transforms from a face-centered cubic crystal to an amorphous state. The XRD patterns of Co/NC-400 retain the partial characteristic peaks of Co-ZIF-9 and no crystalline planes of face-centered cubic Co, indicating that the calcination temperature of 400 °C cannot reduce Co2+ to metallic Co. Additionally, characteristic peaks for Co oxides (such as CoO and Co3O4) are observed. Fig. 4(b) depicts the XRD patterns of the Cu0.04Co1-ZIF-9 and CuxCo1/NC-450 samples. The typical diffraction peaks recorded for Cu0.04Co1-ZIF-9 agree with the pattern of Co-ZIF-9, suggesting that the Co-ZIF-9 morphology was not destroyed. The XRD patterns of Cu0.01Co1/NC-450, Cu0.04Co1/NC-450, Cu0.07Co1/NC-450, and Cu0.10Co1/NC-450 also display visible peaks at 44.22°, 51.52°, and 75.85°, attributed to the (111), (200), and (220) crystal planes of Co. However, after doping with Cu atoms, the peaks corresponding to the Cu phase show no noticeable change for Cu0.01Co1/NC-450, Cu0.04Co1/NC-450, and Cu0.07Co1/NC-450. The XRD pattern of Cu0.10Co1/NC-450 displays peaks at 43.30°, 50.43°, and 74.13°, corresponding to the (111), (200), and (220) crystal planes of Cu (PDF#04–0836), respectively, demonstrating the high dispersibility of Cu atoms in nitrogen-doped carbon. The size and distribution of Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) subsequently. As shown clearly in the Fig. 5 (a) and (b), dispersed Co and Cu NPs with size around 5∼30 nm were observed, and the slight agglomeration may be caused by calcination at high temperature. Furthermore, clear lattice fringes were observed with interplanar spacings of approximately 2.07 Å, 2.04 Å and 1.79 Å (Fig. 5(c) and (d)), which were assigned to the (111) crystal planes of Cu and the (111) and (200) crystal planes of Co, respectively. Therefore, the intimate interface between metallic Cu and metallic Co explains the strong interaction between them, which may lead to the synergistic catalysis between Cu-Co. CO2-TPD was employed to investigate the adsorption ability for CO2 on Co/NC-450 and Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 catalysts. As depicted in Fig. 6 , the peak at around 440 °C of Co/NC-450 catalyst originate from medium and strong basic site, which was ascribed to the chemisorbed CO2 on the NC support surface [38]. Compared with the Co/CN catalyst, Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 catalyst showed a larger desorption peak at 480 °C, which was assigned to medium and strong basic site. This result confirms that there are more basic sites on the surface of Cu0.04Co1/NC-450, which can be explained by the existence of stronger metal-metal and metal-N-C support interactions after doping with Cu element [41]. 3.2 Comparison of the activity of different catalysts The performance of the different catalysts was studied for the selective hydrogenation of HMF, and the results are shown in Table 2 . The hydrogenation of HMF did not occur in the absence of any catalyst (Table 2, entry 1). First, we investigated the role of nitrogen-doped carbon material catalysts containing different metals (Zn, Cu, Ni, and Co) in the hydrogenation of HMF (Table 2, entries 2, 3, 4, and 5). Surprisingly, 87.4% conversion of HMF was achieved only when the Co/NC-500 catalyst was used, while the conversion did not exceed 18% when using Zn/NC-500, Cu/NC-500, and Ni/NC-500 catalysts. The main product was BHMF, and the by-products were 5-MF, MFA, and DMF, respectively, which was consistent with our previous reports [42]. Furthermore, the effect of the calcination temperature of the catalyst precursor (Co-ZIF-9) was explored in the hydrogenation of HMF into BHMF. The hydrogenation of HMF did not occur with the Co/NC-400 catalyst (Table 2, entry 6) because Co-ZIF-9 did not pyrolyze and Co2+ did not reduce to Co NPs at the calcination temperature of 400 °C, which was confirmed by TG analysis and XRD. It is worth noting that 96.0% conversion of HMF and 76.5% selectivity of BHMF were achieved with the Co/NC-450 catalyst, where the calcination temperature was 450 °C (Table 2, entry 7). Upon further increasing the calcination temperature from 450 to 600 °C, the HMF conversion decreased from 96.0% to 10.8% and the BHMF selectivity decreased from 76.5% to 63.4% (Table 2, entries 5, 8, and 9). The results confirm that the Co NPs agglomerated under high-temperature calcination, which severely reduced the activity of the catalyst for HMF hydrogenation. This agglomeration is also evidenced by the decrease in the diffraction peaks of Co at this calcination condition (Fig. 4(a)). To improve the selectivity of BHMF, we prepared catalysts by doping Co/NC-450 with different metals (Zn, Ni, and Cu; Table 2, entries 10, 11, and 15, respectively) and applied them to the hydrogenation of HMF into BHMF. Compared with those for the Co/NC-450 catalyst, the HMF conversion and BHMF selectivity decreased significantly for the Zn0.10Co1/NC-450 and Ni0.10Co1/NC-450 catalysts. Interestingly, the selectivity of BHMF reached 96.5%, but the conversion decreased to 34.7% when the Cu0.10Co1/NC-450 catalyst was used. Therefore, we prepared CuxCo1/NC-450 catalysts with different Cu:Co molar ratios and observed their effect on the BHMF selectivity in the hydrogenation of HMF (Table 2, entries 12, 13, 14, and 15). Compared with the Co/NC-450 catalyst, the conversion of HMF did not change significantly, and the selectivity of BHMF increased to 84.8% for Cu0.01Co1/NC-450. Subsequently, 93.7% conversion of HMF and 92.4% BHMF selectivity were obtained when Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 was used. It can be seen that with increasing Cu:Co molar ratios from 0.04:1 to 0.10:1, the HMF conversion decreases due to the agglomeration of active metals and the possible formation of a solid solution between Cu and Co [43]. These results indicate that doping with Cu results in electron transfer between Cu and Co (as demonstrated by XPS); therefore, the synergistic catalysis of the newly formed Cu-Co sites could be responsible for the increase in the BHMF selectivity during HMF hydrogenation. 3.3 Optimization of the reaction conditions for the hydrogenation of HMF To explore the optimal reaction conditions for the hydrogenation of HMF into BHMF, the effects of the reaction temperature, reaction time, catalyst amount, and H2 pressure were thoroughly investigated. The effects of these parameters on the conversion and selectivity of the reaction are presented in Fig. 7 . The hydrogenation of 5-HMF was carried out in the temperature range of 70 to 120 °C, and the results are shown in Fig. 7(a). Initially, the conversion of 5-HMF was low at lower reaction temperatures (70 and 80 °C), but a higher selectivity of BHMF was obtained (96.5% and 94.3%, respectively). When the reaction temperature was increased to 100 °C, an increase in HMF conversion (93.6%) was observed, and the selectivity of BHMF remained at a high level. This suggests that the reaction temperature has a significant influence on the catalytic activity. Upon further increasing the reaction temperature to 120 °C, the selectivity of BHMF decreased to 80.0%. At the same time, the selectivities of MFA and 5-MF increased, indicating that high temperatures promoted the hydrogenolysis reaction of HMF and BHMF to produce 5-MF and MFA, respectively. Fig. 7(b) shows the results obtained within the variable reaction time range of 0.5–5 h. With increasing reaction time from 0.5 to 4 h, the HMF conversion gradually increased from 30.6% to 93.7%, with an almost constant BHMF selectivity of 92.4%. With an increase in the reaction time to 5 h, the HMF conversion and BHMF selectivity did not change noticeably. This indicates that the hydrogenation reaction reached chemical equilibrium, which can be attributed to the fact that the residual substrate that adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst cannot undergo subsequent hydrogenation reactions. Additionally, the effect of the catalyst amount (10–35 wt.% relative to the substrate) on the production of BHMF was investigated at 100 °C for 4 h (Fig. 7(c)). It is well known that the catalytic capacity depends significantly on the number of active sites. The conversion of HMF increased rapidly with an increase in the catalyst amount. When the catalyst amount was increased to 30 wt.%, a maximum HMF conversion of 93.5% could be attained. However, the HMF conversion did not continue to increase when the catalyst amount was further increased to 35 wt.%. Notably, the conversion of HMF was always > 93.7%. It was found that the catalyst amount had a significant effect on the conversion of HMF, but had a negligible impact on the selectivity of BHMF, indicating that the selectivity of BHMF was independent of the catalyst amount. The H2 pressure plays an important role in the selective hydrogenation of HMF. Accordingly, the effects of different H2 pressures on the performance of the Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 catalyst were studied (Fig. 7(d)). The conversion of HMF increased rapidly with an increase in H2 pressures from 0.25 to 1.00 MPa. The maximum HMF conversion of 93.7% and BHMF selectivity of 92.4% were obtained with the use of 1.00 MPa H2. Upon increasing the H2 pressure to 1.25 MPa, the conversion of HMF remained almost unchanged, but the selectivity of BHMF decreased to 86.9%, because a high hydrogen pressure facilitates the hydrogenolysis of HMF and BHMF to produce 5-MF and MFA, respectively. Furthermore, the effect of solvent on the hydrogenation of HMF to BHMF was investigated, as shown in Fig. S2. It found that Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 catalyst can maintain high catalytic activity in different solvents (such as THF, MeOH, EtOH, 1-PrOH and 2-PrOH) to obtain high yield of BHMF. This indicates that the hydrogen source required for this reaction is provided by hydrogen instead of alcohol solvent. 3.4 Catalyst reusability It is well known that catalytic stability is of particular importance in heterogeneous catalytic processes. Hence, the recyclability of the Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 catalyst was investigated, as shown in Fig. 8 . After each reaction cycle, the Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 catalyst was separated by applying a magnetic field, washed with THF 3–5 times, and vacuum-dried at 60 °C for subsequent catalytic cycles. The HMF conversion decreased from 99.8% to 77.4% after nine consecutive reaction runs, and the BHMF selectivity remained above 90% in the reaction. Notably, the conversion of HMF increased to 90.6% in the tenth cycle, when a fresh catalyst was added until the initial catalyst weight was reached. Furthermore, in order to investigate the structural changes of the Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 catalyst after 10 cycles, the used Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 were also characterized by XPS and TEM. As shown in Fig. S3–6, the surface morphology and structural properties of the catalysts did not change significantly compared with the fresh catalysts. This suggests that an inevitable mass loss during catalyst recycling is the reason for the reduction in the catalytic activity. Conclusions In summary, we fabricated a bimetallic catalyst with nitrogen-doped carbon (Cu-Co/NC), featuring a cubic Cu-Co core and a porous structure derived from ZIFs. Compared to other catalysts, Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 showed high selectivity and activity for the hydrogenation of HMF into BHMF. This can be attributed to the highly dispersed Co NPs in the nitrogen-doped carbon framework, which form Co-Nx species. Furthermore, the synergistic catalytic effect of Cu and Co was demonstrated to be beneficial for the hydrogenation of HMF to BHMF. With the addition of Cu to Co/NC-450, electron transfer occurred from Co to Cu. Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 showed excellent stability for the hydrogenation of HMF into BHMF even after ten cycles. Consequently, the Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 catalyst could catalyze the hydrogenation of HMF to BHMF with good recyclability, high selectivity, and high activity. This work opens a new avenue for the rational design of bimetallic catalysts with nitrogen-doped carbon to achieve the efficient conversion and utilization of biomass resources. coredata.dc:description: Production of the 2,5-Bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF) has important scientific value and strategic significance for the development of new biodegradable polyester materials. Herein, Cu-Co/NC composites containing bimetallic nanoparticles in nitrogen-doped carbon were produced by the calcination of zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs). They featured a cubic Cu-Co core and a porous structure derived from the ZIFs. The surface morphology, surface area, and composition of the catalysts were analyzed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscope (TEM), thermogravimetric (TG) analysis, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray diffraction (XRD), CO2-temperature program desorption (CO2-TPD), and N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms. A conversion of 93.7% of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) with a BHMF selectivity of 92.4% was achieved using the Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 catalyst at a relatively low reaction temperature and H2 pressure. This outstanding catalytic performance was ascribed to the high dispersion of Co nanoparticles in the NC framework, forming Co-Nx species. We found that the synergistic catalysis of Cu-Co sites due to electron transfer contributed to the increase in the BHMF selectivity during HMF hydrogenation. The intensity of the XRD peaks corresponding to metallic Co decreased as the calcination temperature increases, which results in agglomeration of Co nanoparticles (NPs), and reduces the catalytic activity in HMF hydrogenation. Additionally, the conversion of HMF during hydrogenation remained stable after using Cu0.04Co1/NC-450 for ten cycles.
coredata.dc:title: Cu-Co nanoparticles supported on nitrogen-doped carbon: An efficient catalyst for hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural into 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan
